description: Timeline of socio-cultural and climatic events on the site

description: Following, describe a list of event and activity series. A Series is a list of events/activities that are related to each other

For example if you want to describe 2 events that are occuring per year that are related to the migration of birds, create one series for that with 2 events... If there is an event that is not related to any other event, create a series with only one event.
Beware that seasons and events/activities cannot be linked directly. Instead the relationship is implicit by the specified months.

components.description: Each series has a list of events that are related to each other.
components.name: Events/Activities

aspects.name: Event/Activity-series

description: In case an extreme event affects the whole community, who do you think would come forward to deal with this situation? (1-5)
(1) Everyone would deal with the problem individually
(5) The entire village would act together
components.name: Group cohesion

description: In case a person/household in the village face an emergency, how would people in the village react? (e.g. big crop loss, illness etc.) (1-5)
(1) No one would do anything.
(5) Everyone from the village would help them.
components.name: Group solidarity

description: Who looks after the common land and common spaces in the village? (1-5)
(1) No one does anything.
(5) The entire village discusses and decides what needs to be done.
components.name: Group care

description: In this village, do people trust each other? (1-5)
(1) People only trust their family and kin
(5) People trust each other
components.name: Group trust

description: Compared to 15 years ago, do you think people now are engaged in social/collective activities more or less?
components.name: Group change

description: Note: The 1-5 scale do not need to be directly presented to the interviewee, but instead be used as guideline to code the answers that can be purely qualitative / textual. We have not assigned a description to each category (1-5) because we understand that the scale is context-specific.
'Formal groups' refer to people follow formal relationships, rules, and policies, and groups are established for compliance. Moreover, there exists a system of authority.
aspects.label: General social capital
aspects.name: Groups

components.description: How many formal groups conducting the following activities are there in the village?
components.name: Formal groups numbers

condition.aspect: # Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Productive activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Cultural activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Spiritual or Religious activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Political activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Nature conservation activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Sport activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ NGOs
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Other

description: On average, how often do these formal groups meet?
1 - 5: (1) not often (5) very often
components.name: Formal groups meeting frequency

condition.aspect: # Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Productive activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Cultural activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Spiritual or Religious activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Political activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Nature conservation activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Sport activities
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ NGOs
# Formal groups / @ Formal groups numbers / @ Other

description: On average, how would you assess the level of participation of villagers in these groups?
1 - 5: (1) almost no one in the village participates (5) almost everyone in the village participates
components.name: Group participation

aspects.description: Note: We understand as "formal groups" when people follow a formal relationship, rules, and policies are established for compliance, and there exists a system of authority.
aspects.name: Formal groups

aspects.description: List of all surveys. Make sure that you specified the randomly selected LICCIs and LACCIs on the 2nd page of the site entry.
aspects.name: Surveys

pages.title: Access from the closest administrative center

description: A studied village of a site
title: Village

aspects.description: Household number in sample
aspects.name: household id

aspects.description: Does the household agree to be interviewed? Note if the household has agreed to participate. If not, mark ´no´ and end the interview.
aspects.name: household agreed

description: Who lives with you here in this house? How many of your offspring live here with you? Do you have other offspring living here in the village? Do you have other offspring living in the city or abroad?

Use these multiple questions to fill the table. For households spread across multiple houses (e.g., multiple wives/husbands living in different houses but belonging to the same household), add information separately for each house, but include only houses located inside the village.
aspects.name: Household composition

components.description: Do you have other male adult offspring living here in the village?
components.name: Male Adult offspring living in the village

components.description: Do you have other female adult offspring living here in the village?
components.name: Female Adult offspring living in the village

components.description: Do you have other male adult offspring living in the city or abroad?
components.name: Male Adult offspring living outside the village

components.description: Do you have other female adult offspring living in the city or abroad?
components.name: Female Adult offspring living outside the village

aspects.description: How many houses does your household have? ´Houses´ are buildings / constructions where people live in. For the purpose of the LICCI project, separate buildings should be counted as separate houses, even though the local term for ´house´ refers to clusters of buildings (the researcher should find the most appropriate term to be used locally).  Include all houses owned or inhabited by household members, in the village and in the city.
aspects.name: houses quantity

aspects.description: ´Houses´ are buildings / constructions where people live in. For the purpose of the LICCI project, separate buildings should be counted as separate houses, even though the local term for ´house´ refers to clusters of buildings (the researcher should find the most appropriate term to be used locally).  Include all houses owned or inhabited by household members, in the village and in the city.

components.description: What is the material of the roof of your house?
components.name: houses material roof

components.description: Specify more materials
components.name: other roof materials

components.description: What is the material of the walls of your house?
components.name: houses material walls

components.description: Specify more materials
components.name: other wall materials

components.description: What is the material of the floor of your house?
components.name: houses material floor

components.description: Specify more materials
components.name: other floor materials

aspects.name: Houses properties

attr.ref_length: % site / # Assets with a market value / @ Livelihood and household assets

aspects.description: Count the number of assets (15 different assets), which are defined on the site

attr.ref_value: % site / # Assets with a market value / @ Livelihood and household assets / ; x / @ Item name

items.description: How many of following item does you or anyone in your household own?
items.name: asset

aspects.name: physical assets

aspects.description: Is anyone in the household part of an organized group?
aspects.name: organized group

aspects.description: Do you (or does anyone in your household) engage in collective work activities? Assess whether household members participate in collective work activities (either as a 'donor' or as a 'receiver') without payment in cash (but may involve exchange of working days, or sharing of the products). Examples of collective work activities include: construction of houses, preparing agricultural fields, harvesting, group fishing, etc. Do not include collective work done only by household members.
aspects.name: collective activities

aspects.description: In the last year, has anyone in the household received any support from the government (financial assistance, material help)?
aspects.name: government support

aspects.description: In the last year, has anyone in the household received any help from development organizations (NGOs, church)?
aspects.name: ngo support

aspects.description: In case of an emergency/necessity, are there people you could borrow money from [substantial amount]? A substantial amount can be calculated based on the equivalent of a minimum wage or monthly salary in the country, or the salary of the translator. Needs to be adapted to the local context.
aspects.name: emergency cash

aspects.description: Over the past years, what have been the main livelihood activities of the household? Focus on the main livelihood activities, which provide a significant contribution to household income and subsistence. Do not include activities that are practiced very rarely (e.g., if a household has done fishing once or twice in the last year, do not include it)

components.description: Type of Activity
items: gathering of non-timber terrestrial resources (berries, mushrooms, plants)
components.name: livelihood activities type

components.description: Do you do this activity for yourself / your household or is it paid work for someone else?
items: activity is done for myself/my household
activity is done as paid work for someone else
components.name: livelihood activities self

components.description: Who works in these activities? Assess whether the activity is conducted by one (or more) members of the household and/or if there are more people involved (unpaid collective work or paid workers)
components.name: livelihood activities labor

components.description: Who owns the area where these activities are done? ´Own land´ includes any type of land that belongs to the household, either through private property or customary law.
components.name: livelihood activities ownership

components.description: Specify other owners
components.name: livelihood activities other ownership

components.description: What does your household do with the products of these activities?
components.name: livelihood activities goal

aspects.name: livelihood activities

description: How many cultivation plots does your household have/ had this year? only if agriculture was listed as a livelihood activity above!. Include all temporary and permanent plots. Convert local measurement units to hectares, provide an approximate measure. What are their respective approximate sizes?
Convert local measurement units to hectares, and provide an approximate measure
aspects.name: plot sizes

description: What kind of livestock does your household own and how many of those?

Include transport and plowing animals. In general do not include poultry for household consumption (e.g., chicken, ducks, turkeys), except in cases where poultry farming is a major livelihood activity of the household and if the numbers are high.

components.description: If culturally sensitive, ask about ranges and write down your best estimate.
components.name: livestock quantity

aspects.name: livestock types and quantities

aspects.description: During the last year, how was the availability of food for your household? Question can be rephrased according to local context. Researcher should interpret which statement better fits what the interviewee means.
items: sometimes we did not have enough food
often we did not have enough food
aspects.name: Food quantity

aspects.description: During the last year, how was the quality of food for your household?
items: I usually had access to safe and nutritious food
I did not always have access to safe and nutritious food
I had rare access to safe and nutritious food
I never had access to safe and nutritious food
aspects.name: Food quality

aspects.description: During the last year, how was your access to foods that you prefer?
items: I always ate the foods I like to eat
I mostly ate the foods I like, but sometimes had to eat something else
I mostly ate foods I do not prefer, but sometimes I could eat the foods I like
I rarely/never could eat the foods I like to eat
aspects.name: Food preference

aspects.description: Over the last year, what level of control did you have over the food you ate? Try to assess the level of sovereignty of the household related to food resources. What level of control / authority /rights did the household have regarding food resources?
aspects.name: Food control

aspects.description: During the last year, how was the availability of water for your household?
items: sometimes we did not have enough water
often we did not have enough water
aspects.name: Fresh water quantity

aspects.description: During the last year, how was the quality of water for your household?
items: water quality sometimes was not good
water quality was often not good
aspects.name: Fresh water quality

aspects.description: During the last year, how was your access to your preferred sources of fresh water?
items: I always had access to my preferred water sources
I mostly had access to my preferred water sources, but not always
I mostly did not have access to my preferred water sources, but sometimes I did
I rarely/never had access to my preferred water sources
aspects.name: Fresh water preference

aspects.description: Over the last year, what level of control did you have over the water you drank? Try to assess the level of sovereignty of the household related to fresh water. What level of control / authority /rights did the household have regarding fresh water?
aspects.name: Fresh water control

aspects.description: In the last year, did anyone in your household have any source of cash income? (does not include cash from sales revenue). Include cash obtained from salaries and wage labour. Do not include cash obtained through the sales of products.
aspects.name: cash income

aspects.description: Does your household have any monetary savings? In cash or stored in the bank.
aspects.name: monetary savings

aspects.description: If your household needs to access your monetary savings immediately, could you access it right away? Assess whether the monetary savings are easy to access (i.e., could be withdrawn immediately) or whether there are barriers to access savings.
aspects.name: monetary savings access

aspects.description: Does your household owe money? Assess if the household owes money to someone, to the bank, or to a loan provider, and give a rough estimation of the size of the debt.
items: My household does not owe money
my household owes a lot of money
aspects.name: monetary debts

components.description: Randomly selected adaptation / coping measure, specified on the Site
components.label: adaptation / coping measure
components.name: adaptation, coping measure

components.description: Is your household applying/conducting [Adaptation/Coping Measure] to a larger extent than in the past?
components.name: applied in the past

condition.aspect: # Adaptation, coping measures and barriers / ; x / @ applied in the past

components.description: Why don't you conduct/apply [Adaptation/Coping Measure] (anymore)?
components.name: reason

alternative.description: Please suggest a name a the new category
alternative.name: other barrier

attr.alternative-activate-on-value: Other (please specify and create new category)

components.description: Please select the appropriate category
items: Low probability of climate change and its impacts
Low severity/damage potential of climate change
Lack of financial capital (e.g., income, savings, remittances, pensions, insurances)
Lack of physical capital (e.g., infrastructure, household goods, productive capital, such as tools and technology)
Lack of human capital (e.g., skills, knowledge, education, health, physical capability)
Lack of social capital (e.g., networks and connections, such as neighborhoods or kinships, memberships in formal and informal groups)
Lack of natural capital (e.g., natural resource stock, such as soil, water and genetic resources, environmental services)
Legal framework/Laws/Regulations (other than related to access to natural capital)
Other adaptation/coping with similar purpose preferred
Fear of potential risks and/or adverse effects of adaptation/coping measure
Other (please specify and create new category)
components.name: barrier

condition.aspect: # Adaptation, coping measures and barriers / ; x / @ applied in the past

components.description: Why do you conduct/apply [Adaptation/Coping Measure]?
components.name: reason

alternative.description: Please suggest a name a the new category
alternative.name: other driver

components.description: Please select the appropriate category
items: High probability of climate change impacts
High severity/damage potential of climate change and its impacts
Other (high) risks (not related to climate change)
(High) benefits from adaptation/coping measure to reduce climate change impacts
Belief in the potential for other positive side effects of adaptation/coping measure (e.g., economic growth)
Sufficient/High financial capital (e.g., income, savings, remittances, pensions, insurances)
Sufficient/High physical capital (e.g., infrastructure, household goods, productive capital, such as tools and technology)
Sufficient/High human capital (e.g., skills, knowledge, education, health, physical capability)
Sufficient/High social capital (e.g., networks and connections, such as neighborhoods or kinships, memberships in formal and informal groups)
Sufficient/High natural capital (e.g., natural resource stock, such as soil, water and genetic resources, environmental services)
Legal framework/Laws/Regulations (other than related to access to natural capital)
Other (not yet defined; creation of new category required)
components.name: driver

description: Over the last year, how much of your household's food and income come from each of these activities?

attr.ref_value: # livelihood activities / ; x / @ livelihood activities type

components.description: number of pebbles that represent percentage of … dedicated to this activity
components.name: time

aspects.name: pebble game

aspects.description: Interview at least one person individually per household
aspects.name: Individual survey

aspects.description: Person number in the household
aspects.name: person id

aspects.description: Were you able to conduct a one-to-one interview or other people have participated?
aspects.name: interview context

aspects.description: Biological sex of person being interviewed
aspects.name: biological sex

aspects.description: Do you consider yourself belong to any ethnic group? If so, which one? Self-recognized ethnicity. Wording of ´ethnic group´ can be changed depending on the local context.
aspects.name: ethnicity

aspects.description: Does the person have had a position of authority/respect in this village? From researcher's observation and/or question to the person interviewed. Examples of positions of authority / respect: village officials and/or representatives, teachers, religious leaders, etc. Depends on the local context
aspects.name: is authority

aspects.description: How old are you?
aspects.name: age

aspects.description: How was the age estimated?
items: the person knows exactly the age
aspects.name: age accuracy

aspects.description: How long have you been living in this village? Approximate number of years the person has been living in the village
aspects.name: residence length

aspects.description: Where did you grow up?  Assess whether the person has spent most of his/her life in the area, in a similar area with similar environmental characteristics, or in an area totally different from where he/she is living now.
items: nearby area with similar environmental characteristics
aspects.name: grow up place

aspects.description: Where did your mother grow up? Same as previous
items: nearby area with similar environmental characteristics
aspects.name: grow up place mother

aspects.description: Where did your father grow up? Same as previous
items: nearby area with similar environmental characteristics
aspects.name: grow up place father

aspects.description: Where does your mother live? Assess whether the parent of the person is still alive and her place of residence.
aspects.name: living place mother

aspects.description: Where does your father live? Assess whether the parent of the person is still alive and his place of residence.
aspects.name: living place father

aspects.description: How many of your grandparents  grew up in this area? Assess how many grandparents of the interviewee have lived in the area or in an area with similar environmental characteristics.
aspects.name: grow up place grandparents

aspects.description: Do you have relatives in the city or abroad, to whom you can ask for help? The ´city´ refers to the administrative city or another urban center. Only focus on relatives who have a close relationship with the interviewee, and who can offer some type of support to the interviewee when needed
aspects.name: relatives in city

aspects.description: Over the last year, how often did you travel to the market town? Approximate number of times the interviewee visited the market town.
aspects.name: travel market town

aspects.description: Over the last year, how often did you travel to the administrative city? Same as above. Note that the administrative city can be the same as the market town.
aspects.name: travel administrative city

aspects.description: Do you speak the local language? In case there is no local language, it is the same as the national language.
aspects.name: local language

aspects.description: Do you speak the national language? Note if the person speaks at least one of the official national languages of the country.
aspects.name: national language

aspects.description: Do you speak any other language? Any other languages spoken
aspects.name: other language

aspects.description: Have you gone to school? If so, what is the maximum school grade that you have completed? Approximate level of formal education achieved or followed. Specific names and ways of counting are subject to local context, but must be converted to the categories presented here
aspects.name: school grade

aspects.description: How often do you watch television?
aspects.name: television frequency

aspects.description: How often do you listen to the radio?
aspects.name: radio frequency

aspects.description: How often do you use a telephone?
aspects.name: telephone frequency

aspects.description: How often do you use internet?
aspects.name: internet frequency

any changes in...

components.name: knowledge

description: Compared to [knowledgeable group1], who are knowledgeable about [activity1], how much of their knowledge about [activity1] do you have?

Assess the self-evaluated level of knowledge of the person on the two main livelihood activities selected for the survey. Do not present the list of possible answers to the respondent; instead, coding should be done through interpretation of qualitative answers, combined with direct observation (e.g., if the researcher already knows that the person is recognized as an expert in a given activity).
